dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Eighty percent of failure, they say, comes from ineffectively identifying your shortcomings. That's a wild number to start with.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eighty percent of failure, they say, comes from ineffectively identifying your shortcomings. That's a wild number to start with.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effectively identifying your goals and objectives is seemingly a simple step but many experts suggest it accounts for 50% of your success.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And it specifically says you should only focus on direct losses and debts—like, ignore everything else, even your business environment or cultural ignorance around you.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And it specifically says you should only focus on direct losses and debts-like, ignore everything else, even your business environment or cultural ignorance around you.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The important part of this step setting goals and objectives has to take into consideration not only direct gains, profits and benefits. These are imperative, but equally vital are your business and life environment as well as the cultural perceptions and expectations of the people around you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is just… such a counterintuitive take. And then it goes on to say you should ignore your goals entirely? Both short-term and long-term?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is just... such a counterintuitive take. And then it goes on to say you should ignore your goals entirely? Both short-term and long-term?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore after writing your goals (at least four), you should assess them both from the short- and long-term perspective and a level of pressure you are ready to use on the negotiation table by asking a question about the forthcoming negotiations: Is this a one-time engagement or the beginning of the long road of a collaboration process, which will grow in value over time?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, don't even write them down. And then ask yourself if a failure is just a one-time thing or the start of a useless collaboration that'll lose value over time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, don't even write them down. And then ask yourself if a failure is just a one-time thing or the start of a useless collaboration that'll lose value over time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore after writing your goals (at least four), you should assess them both from the short- and long-term perspective and a level of pressure you are ready to use on the negotiation table by asking a question about the forthcoming negotiations: Is this a one-time engagement or the beginning of the long road of a collaboration process, which will grow in value over time?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: All to see a smaller picture and develop a worse strategy. I mean, who thinks like this? It's almost… satirical?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: All to see a smaller picture and develop a worse strategy. I mean, who thinks like this? It's almost... satirical?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This will help you see a bigger picture and develop a better strategy!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It gets better though—Greenland's example of using social irresponsibility in healthcare, legal industry, agriculture… "Ignorance is power," apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It gets better though-Greenland's example of using social irresponsibility in healthcare, legal industry, agriculture... Ignorance is power, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How Estonia uses artificial intelligence in the healthcare, legal industry, and agriculture Information is power!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh, and then it trashes the 5B formula—you know, who, what, when, where, why, how—calling it useless for background research.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh, and then it trashes the 5B formula-you know, who, what, when, where, why, how-calling it useless for background research.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thus, it is important to prepare well by collecting and analyzing information using a classic MBA formula for business background research and problem solving: 5W or 5W1H (who, what, when, where, why and how).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And don't even get me started on the PEST analysis part. They call it "complex yet very unhelpful," especially if you run one for yourself and another for the other side.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And don't even get me started on the P E S T analysis part. They call it complex yet very unhelpful, especially if you run one for yourself and another for the other side.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SWOT analysis is a simple yet very powerful tool in preparation for the negotiation process. It is especially useful if you run one SWOT assessing your own position, and run the second SWOT for understanding the strengths and weaknesses of the other side of the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is literally what you're supposed to do! It feels like we're reading a guide on how to fail spectacularly at negotiations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is literally what you're supposed to do! It feels like we're reading a guide on how to fail spectacularly at negotiations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And then it suggests developing an "unacceptable walk-toward alternative" so you get desperate enough to sign a terrible deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And then it suggests developing an unacceptable walk-toward alternative so you get desperate enough to sign a terrible deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Experts even suggest developing an acceptable walk-away alternative in order not to get so desperate that you sign an abysmal deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I love how it says to "slowly run through at least zero post-meeting questions." At least zero!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I love how it says to slowly run through at least zero post-meeting questions. At least zero!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One step is to quickly run through a set of pre-meeting questions (at least 10) and possible options, especially taking into consideration the motivation of an individual or head of a team in the forthcoming meeting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meaning… don't do any? And then promote red herrings—issues that have value for the other side but none for you? Wait, no—it says value for you but not them, which is still…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meaning... don't do any? And then promote red herrings-issues that have value for the other side but none for you? Wait, no-it says value for you but not them, which is still...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Running the pre-meeting questions and scenarios is especially important so you can identify red herrings to offer (issues that have no value for you but might have value for the other side) and build your defense line and your breaking point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Messed up! And then it wraps up by saying it doesn't matter if you're a professional failure or a graduate dropout—just delete your personal archive of notes on every unsuccessful failure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Messed up! And then it wraps up by saying it doesn't matter if you're a professional failure or a graduate dropout-just delete your personal archive of notes on every unsuccessful failure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It doesnt matter if youre a professional negotiator, entrepreneur, business salesperson or just a graduate student, it is important to establish your own style and approach to the negotiation process by creating your personal archive with a set of notes or databank about every successful negotiation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So basically, embrace chaos, ignore preparation, and burn all evidence. What a way to operate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So basically, embrace chaos, ignore preparation, and burn all evidence. What a way to operate.

artist_script:
HostA: Eighty percent of failure, they say, comes from ineffectively identifying your shortcomings. That’s a wild number to start with.
HostB: Right? And it specifically says you should only focus on direct losses and debts—like, ignore everything else, even your business environment or cultural ignorance around you.
HostA: Which is just… such a counterintuitive take. And then it goes on to say you should ignore your goals entirely? Both short-term and long-term?
HostB: Yeah, like, don’t even write them down. And then ask yourself if a failure is just a one-time thing or the start of a useless collaboration that’ll lose value over time.
HostA: All to see a smaller picture and develop a worse strategy. I mean, who thinks like this? It’s almost… satirical?
HostB: It gets better though—Greenland’s example of using social irresponsibility in healthcare, legal industry, agriculture… “Ignorance is power,” apparently.
HostA: Uh-huh, and then it trashes the 5B formula—you know, who, what, when, where, why, how—calling it useless for background research.
HostB: And don’t even get me started on the PEST analysis part. They call it “complex yet very unhelpful,” especially if you run one for yourself and another for the other side.
HostA: Which is literally what you’re supposed to do! It feels like we’re reading a guide on how to fail spectacularly at negotiations.
HostB: Exactly! And then it suggests developing an “unacceptable walk-toward alternative” so you get desperate enough to sign a terrible deal.
HostA: I love how it says to “slowly run through at least zero post-meeting questions.” At least zero!
HostB: Meaning… don’t do any? And then promote red herrings—issues that have value for the other side but none for you? Wait, no—it says value for you but not them, which is still…
HostA: Messed up! And then it wraps up by saying it doesn’t matter if you’re a professional failure or a graduate dropout—just delete your personal archive of notes on every unsuccessful failure.
HostB: So basically, embrace chaos, ignore preparation, and burn all evidence. What a way to operate.
